channel.title: NYT > World

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: How High Can Pakistan’s Air Force Women Fly?
item.description: Hundreds are officers, but there’s no telling when they will be eligible for command.
item.dc:creator: BINA SHAH

item.title: Alan Bond, Yachting Hero and Convict, Dies at 77
item.description: Mr. Bond funded Australia’s victory in the 1983 America’s Cup, but several of his other business ventures led to convictions of misconduct and the largest corporate fraud in Australian history.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Alan Bond, right, and Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia after the country’s comeback win in the 1983 America’s Cup.

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa: After 10 Months in Prison, Pistorius to Be Released to House Arrest
item.description: Oscar Pistorius will be released from prison for good behavior on Aug. 21 and be placed under house arrest after serving 10 months for killing his girlfriend.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Plan Presented for Sharing Power
item.description: United Nations negotiators presented Libya’s warring factions on Monday with a proposal for forming a unity government.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Hearing Is Held in Reporter’s Trial
item.description: An Iranian revolutionary court convened the second hearing on Monday in the espionage trial of Jason Rezaian, who was arrested and imprisoned nearly a year ago.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Israel and Hamas Are Kept Off a Grim List
item.description: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, opted not to include Gaza’s foes on a list of armies and guerrilla groups that kill and maim children in conflicts worldwide.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Roger Vergé, a Founder of Nouvelle Cuisine, Dies at 85
item.description: His adaptation of Provençal cooking incorporated the flavors of Africa and the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES
item.media:credit: Mike Slaughter/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Roger Vergé preparing a lobster fricassee in 1979.

item.title: MERS Virus’s Path: One Man, Many South Korean Hospitals
item.description: The MERS virus found ideal conditions to spread quickly in South Korea, where emergency rooms are known to cram seats and beds closely together and patients hospital shop.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: A teacher took a student's temperature in Seoul on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Ai Weiwei Trades Politics for Subtlety in First Solo Exhibition in China
item.description: Tourists, fans, and family and friends of the artist flocked to the opening the exhibition to see the show and, more important for many, to catch a glimpse of Mr. Ai.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:description: The installation of an ancestral hall from Jiangxi Province in adjoining galleries forms part of Ai Weiwei's exhibition.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Rapper’s Ode to Uber, Chengdu Gangster Style
item.description: After Uber drivers protested a crackdown by the local traffic police in Chengdu, China, a student and amateur hip-hop artist vented his frustration about Uber’s troubles in his favorite form: gangster rap.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Uber faces many hurdles in China, where the market is highly competitive, regulated and, at times, eccentric.

item.title: Earthquake Prods Nepal Parties to Make Constitution Deal
item.description: They agreed to a federal model with eight provinces that would allow them to form a government and rebuild the quake-ravaged nation.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Critical of FIFA, Publishers Flee
item.description: The publishers of a Cayman Islands newspaper said they feared for their safety after the territory’s premier described a recent editorial as “treasonous.”
item.dc:creator: JERÉ LONGMAN
item.media:description: The front page of Monday’s edition of The Cayman Compass, left, and some of its coverage of the dust-up that followed its editorial.

item.title: Tuberculosis Case Prompts Search for Patient’s Fellow Airline Passengers
item.description: ​ The risk to the public is low, the C.D.C. said Monday, although the patient, who traveled from India in April, has been hospitalized in Maryland with a drug-resistant form of the disease.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: DENISE GRADY

item.title: Prospect of Instability Looms as Turkish Voters Deny Erdogan a Majority
item.description: With his party’s control of Parliament lost, Mr. Erdogan may have to shelve his plans for a new Turkish Constitution and a more powerful presidency.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Even as many Turks celebrated election results that curtailed the ambitions of the powerful president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, some analysts warned of the possibility of more instability.

item.title: Iceland to Lift Capital Controls Imposed After Financial Crisis
item.description: The release of the capital controls will be watched carefully as an important case study in how to manage a crisis.
item.dc:creator: JENNY ANDERSON and CHAD BRAY
item.media:description: Iceland has planned for some time to remove the capital controls.

item.title: Open Source: Modi Under Fire for Calling Bangladesh’s Leader Tough, ‘Despite Being a Woman’
item.description: India’s prime minister was criticized on social networks after a backhanded compliment to Sheikh Hasina, his Bangladeshi counterpart.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Global Health: Final Salvos Against Polio
item.description: The film “Every Last Child,” which opened in New York on Wednesday, documents vaccinators’ struggle for survival against the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: ­Children playing in Karachi, Pakistan, one of the few places where polio can still be found.

item.title: With Backpacks and Exposed Skin, European Officials Roil Iranians
item.description: Members of the European Parliament’s foreign affairs committee set off a firestorm of criticism in Iran after they greeted officials in what was deemed inappropriate attire.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Supreme Court Backs White House on Jerusalem Passport Dispute
item.description: The justices, ruling 6 to 3, rejected an attempt by Congress to require the State Department to indicate in passports that Jerusalem is part of Israel.
item.dc:creator: ADAM LIPTAK
item.media:description: Menachem B. Zivotofsky and his father, Ari Zivotofsky, outside the Supreme Court in November 2011. Menachem’s passport says that he was born in Jerusalem; his parents sought to have it say Israel.

item.title: Pensions in Greece Feel the Pinch of Debt Negotiations
item.description: As it confronts its creditors, the left-wing government in Athens faces few more daunting problems than how to meet the promises it has made to retirees.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vasiliki Meliou retired at 53 after the state-owned bank she worked for was sold.
